question: How does a second-price bid auction work?

options.A: The highest bidder wins and pays the highest bid
options.B: The bidder who offers the second highest price gets an item at the second highest price.
options.C: The bidder who offers the second highest price gets an item at the highest price.
options.D: The bidder who offers the highest price gets an item at the second highest price.

question: In this game you are in the role of _______?

options.C: An information provider who holds knowledge regarding the true worth of the auctioned item.

question: What is the difference between the two options (auction setting) presented to you?

options.B: In one auction, all bidders have the same evaluation, and in the second auction, there is a set of probabilities of the second-highest bid.
options.C: In one auction, you know how much the item is worth to you and in the second auction, you don’t know.
options.D: In one auction, you are in the role of a bidder, and in the second auction, you are in the role of an auctioneer.

question: What is known to you in a “same evaluation” auction?

options.B: Your evaluation and thus your bid for the auctioned item.
options.C: The set of probabilities of the different options of the second highest bid.

question: What is known to you in a “set of probabilities” auction?

options.C: The set of probabilities of the different options of the second highest bid.

options.A: In the “same evaluation” auction, you will pay the presented bid, while in the “set of probabilities” auction, you will pay the second-highest bid according to the set of probabilities shown.
options.B: In a “same evaluation” auction, you will definitely win, while in a “set of probabilities” auction, you will not win.
options.C: In a “same evaluation” auction, you will pay the presented bid, while in a “set of probabilities” auction, you will pay according to the average of the bids presented.
options.D: In a “same evaluation” auction, you will pay the presented bid, while in a “set of probabilities” auction, you will pay the highest bid presented.

question: What is your goal in this game, and how is the score in each round calculated?

options.A: Your goal is to maximize your expected profit. Your score is the expected profit of the chosen option.
options.B: Your goal is to maximize your expected profit. In case of winning, your profit is your valuation minus your payment (second highest bid plus participation fee if required).
options.C: Your goal is to maximize your expected profit. If you don't win, no payment is required (unless a participation fee is required), and no gain will be received.
options.D: Answers B and C are correct

options.A: No, because it doesn’t make sense.
options.B: Yes, it can happen when participating in an auction with a participation fee where you win and the second highest bid is the same as your valuation.
options.C: Yes, it can happen when participating in an auction with a participation fee where you win and the second highest bid plus participation fee is below your valuation.
options.D: No, because you win when your valuation equals or surpasses the second-highest bid, and therefore your profit is positive. If you don't win, no payment is required.

question: Why one would choose to participate in the “set of probabilities” auction?

options.A: Because in some cases you may get a higher profit than the “same evaluation” option.
options.B: Because if you don't win, no payment is required, and no gain will be received.
options.C: Because you get a set of second highest bids instated of single evaluation.
options.D: Because in the “same evaluation” option you always lose.

question: Why one would not choose to participate in the “set of probabilities” auction?

options.A: Because in some cases you may get a higher profit in the “same evaluation” option.
options.B: Because in some cases you may lose the auction and gain nothing.
options.C: Because in some cases “set of probabilities” auction may yield negative profit.
options.D: All of the above are correct.
